By STUART SEIDEL
In response to a Student Council proposal
requesting the "University administration to
Close down all University operations on October
1 5" in coordination with the nationwide
Vietnam Moratorium, President Lincoln Gordon
has issued a new policy statement which confirms his earlier stand on the Monatorium.
The resolution, introduced and passed at the
SC's last meeting calls for the entire University
community to actively participate in the
Upcoming Moratorium. At a previous meeting,
the council voted support for the Hopkins ad
hoc committee for the Vietnam Moratorium.
The new resolution condemns the "continued
involvement of the United States in Vietnam"
and endorses the "proposal by Senator Charles
Goodell of New York calling for a withdrawal of
all United States forces from Vietnam by the
end of 1979.Faculty Support
The SC also called upon the _faculty of the
University "to support the Vietnam Moratorium
by cancelling all classes on October 15." Eleven
faculty members had already begun to circulate
a letter and petition of support for the
Moratorium.
The resolution, introduced by junior class
representative Bill Betcher, pointed out that the
presidents of Rutgers 'University and the
University of Michigan have already called for
school-wide participation in the Moratorium at
their respective schools. The resolution
encouraged the Hopkins administration to take
similar steps by saying "in view of the
importance of this day both for the University
and for the entire country, we feel that the
University has an obligation to particpate in the
observance of the Moratorium."
In a statement released on September 30, Dr.
Gordon responded to the SC resolution passed
the day before. The President cited a letter he
had written on March 21, 1968 to a faculty
member who had requested that the University

be closed down for the "Academic Days of
Conscience." In that letter he denied the request
because, "In substance. .. several of your
suggestions, including the suspension of regular
classes ... would imply the adoption of an
official, institutional, University position in
relation to the war."
The letter continues,"... Johns Hopkins has
always maintainerl an exceptionally liberal
attitude towards the expression of views on
matters of public interest and concern by all
members of the University community. There is
no inhibition on individual or organized
manifestations of opinion, so long as they do
not impair the freedom of others orinterfere
with the normal functioning of the University."
"Constrained"
"On the other hand," wrote Dr. Gordon,
"the University has never adopted an official
institutional position on controverted public
issues, and I believe that it would be most
undesirable for it to do so. Members of the
community, whether a majority or a minority,
who differed from the 'official position'
would inevitably feel constrained by its very
announcement.'
President Gordon did state that although the
administration would not support the
Moratorium it would not prohibit to members
of the University community participation in its
activities. The President's statement reads
"... this conclusion in no way prevents
individual students, faculty members,
administrators, or groupings of them to make
crystal clear their opinions on policy concerning
the warm n Vietnam or any other issue." Dr.
Gordon also indicates that "The freedom of
students to attend particular classes or not on an
individual voluntary basis is equally well
established."
The President's statement says, "Institutional
university positions on matters of public policy
not directly affecting the academic enterprise
are simply not compatible with the intransigent

he by

defense of academic freedom, a cause which this
University has consistently defended since its
very foundation."
Personal Views
Explaining his personal views of the war in
Vietnam Dr. Gordon cited a personal requrest
from President Lyndon Johnson in March, 1968
for his opinions on the war. Dr. Gordon said, "I
stated clearly my opinion that the decisions
made in 1954, 1961, and 1965 (by Eisenhower,
Kennedy and Johnson respectively) had been
mistaken. I recommended a policy of prompt
de-Americanization of the militaty and
'pacification' efforts and a broader political base
for the government in Saigon." President
Gordon points out that coincidentally his views
are "parallel to Defense Secretary Clifford's
proposals as he related them in Foreign Affairs
last July."
President Gordon sees some efforts in this
direction, but considers them to be "too small
and too halting." Even considering the state of
the war today Dr. Gordon does not think that
unilateral withdrawal is the best course."If I did
believe so, I would want it done much more
rapidly than the fifteen months suggested in
Senator Goodell's resolution."
"Moral Obligation"
The President sees the possibility for a
political settlement as not "wholly unrealizable,
within a short time period." He also believes
that the United States has a "moral obligation in
any circumstances to provide for the safety of
individuals in South Vietnam who have relied on
our commitments — however unwisely
made — in recent years."

last year, challenged the Council's
authority to appropriate funds for a
student-run course.

the Council had overstepped its bounds
by passing a proposal for The Johns
Hopkins University Visiting Lectureship
Chair.

Rodriguez, was adopted overwhelmingly

SC, suggested at that time that the
motion be tabled pending further study
and investigation oi campus opinion.

University, proved to contain certain

appointment of visiting faculty
members.

The Academic Council, individually
and collectively, has decided to ignore
Dr: George Owen's proposal for a
university senate and instead will
proceed with its own plans and
time-table for changes in the governance
of Homewood.
The 17-member Council, in a closed
meeting last Wednesday, agreed to begin
distributing to the faculty and students
an agenda of its future gatherings a
week in advance and publish afterwards
the decisions reached at the meeting.
However, the position of individual
Academic Council members on the
various issues on the agenda, their
voting patterns and all "confidential
matters" will not be disclosed, stated
Dean Allyn Kimball. He defined
confidential matters as hearings for
Possible promotions, incompetency and
other issues that may be "personally
embarrassing to a faculty member."
According to Kimball, the Council
also discussed the need for reforms in
the governing structure of the
University during last week's meeting.
A lot of faculty feel that the Academic
Council should not be the body to cope
with all the problems on campus, but
Should be concerned only with
academic policies," the dean observed.
He stated that the Academic Council
will probably decide the procedures for
studying Hopkins' structure of
goverment during its October 15
meeting. The Council, Kimball
predicted, will appoint a study group
which in turn will select a second
committee charged to draft a proposal
for reforms in the University's
governance procedures. Kimball said
that this second group should include
undergraduate and graduate students.
The Academic Council's discussions
last Wednesday were prompted by a
report presented by Dr. M. Gordon
Wolman, a Council member, proposing a
study of a new structure for governing
Homewood. Although he declined to
endorce the senate idea, he said that it
was conveivable that a new
representative body may be created by
next September.
With the exception of Dr. Peter
Rossi, chairman of the social relations
department and Dean Robert Strider, all
the other members of the Academic
Council contacted refused to spell out
their positions on the Owen proposal.
Drs. Stanley Corrsin of the
mechanics department, Ferdinand
Hamburger, Jr. of electrical engineering,
Dean Carl Swanson and three other
faculty members of the Academic
Council declined to express their
Opinions on the university senate. Most
said they needed time to think it over.
"Feasible and Reasonable"

senate plan appeared "feasible and
reasonable," and he expressed a desire
for its approval. The social relations
chairman endorsed the idea of a
fifty-fifty split between students and
faculty members in the proposed senate.
"There is probably more wisdom in the
university body than in the Academic
Council," he asserted.
The right for student attendence at
all university meetings, though, was

cautioned against abuses in student

Detrick Chief Forced to Forego Symposium
"It's too bad the general public doesn't
understand that we are working in their best
interests," lamented Dr. Riley Housewright,
civilian director of the Army's Fort Detrick
center for chemical and biological warfare
(CBW)research.
Housewright was ordered last ,week by
high-echelon Pentagon officials to back out on a
month-old commitment to discuss the
controversial CBW issue in an appearance at
Hopkins. He complied.
Housewright had been slated to participate in a
November 12 panel discussion as part of Hopkins'
annual Niilton S. Eisenhower Symposium series. "Arms
Control" is this year's topic.
Symposium co-chairmen, William Botcher and S.P.
Mahainka, expressed disappointment with the turn of
events. Betcher is "extremely disgusted and appalled
with the Pentagon."
Pentagon Irks Mahinka
"We want to generate public debate on issues, but
they won't participate in it,— added Mahinka.
The Pentagon letter to Dr. Housewright, which
objects to his planned appearance states that "in view of
current widespread criticism (of the CBW program) by
members of the U.S. political and scientific community,
whatever marginal benefits might be gained tend to be
overshadowed by the additonal embarrassment to the
Army."
When questioned about the ratiOnale behind the
letter, Colonel B. Udegaard, a Pentagon information
officer, exclaimed, "I don't even know what you're
talking about!Don't Want to Get Involved
Under prodding, Udegaard admitted that it is "not
standard policy at this time" for high-ranking officials in
controversial positions to "get involved in what might
become a public debate."
This policy is particularly applicable to CBW

personnel, since the entire program is currently under
review by the National Security Council at Presidential
request.
Housewright affirmed the existence of such a policy,
but acknowledged that he "really would have liked to
come. We need a lot more of this sort of discussion."
Brigadier General William Stone, the present Director
of CBW in the Pentagon, also turned down a Symposium
vitation for reasons similar-to Housewright's.
R&D on CBW
Fort Detrick, located in Frederick, Maryland, is the
US center for the research and development of biological
warfare agents. Utilizing the recent advances in genetics,
researchers at the base have been developing techniques
that will enable them to develop a variety of diseases
such as bubonic plague, pneumonic plague, and anthra,
that nd longer could be cured by current antibiotics.
Nearly 3000 civilians and military men work at
Detrick, hoping to discover potential new disease agents
and then learning to defend against them. The work has
been termed "biological ,engineering" by the. germ
warriors of Detrick.
Some 530 million a year is spent at Detrick for these
purposes. Its professional staff includes 120 men with
PH.D. degrees in such fields as microbiology and
biomathematics; 110 men with M.A. degrees, and 320
B.S. degree-holders. The base also has four medical
doctors and 34 veterinarians on its staff. The vets are in
charge of the more than 720,000 animals ranging from
guinea pigs to monkeys which are killed each year in
biological experimentation and similar research.

Excessive Security
Until recently, what was going on at Detrick was
considered exclusively the military's business: the fort is
one of three U.S. bases devoted to furthering the art of
biological warfare. CBW has recently been the subject of
growing nationwide protest, spurred by military
accidents and excessive secrecy surrounding the entire
program.

The protests, led by Richard D. McCarthy, Democrat
of New York, who almost singlehandedly pursued the
issue in news conferences and on the House floor,
reached a peak i
Mid-August when the Senate
unanimously passed a series of curbs on the esting and
shipping of CBW agents.
McCarthy is scheduled to be on the November 17.
panel on CBW of the Eisenhower Symposium, from
which Housewright and Stone'canceled. Now scheduled
for the panel, in addition to the Democratic
Congressman, are Seymour M. Hersh, author of
"Chemical and Biological Warfare: America's Hidden
Arsenal," and Colonel Norman I. Shapiro, U.S. Army
(retired), presently with Litton Industries.
Alas and Alack
Housewright lamented the lack of sufficient
discussion on CBW. "What we need is a better
understanding of the entire situtation. If people don't
understand something, it should be discussed in more
depth from both points of view," he noted.
"The President's current review of chemical and
biological warfare probable has a great deal to do with
.(this decision)" he continued. Housewright indicated
that he disagrees with the Amry's policy of not allowing
army employees to speak on CpW.
"I admit that the Army has not had a very good PR
program in the last six months." Housewright has been
asked to speak at Rutgers, Stanford, Mexico City. He has

By ED MENDELSOHN
At this point in the study of Alton B.
Parker it is necessary to retreat twenty
years, so that not coincidentally—there
will be a closer examination of the
principal advocate of Parker's election,
former President Cleveland. The
standard comment on the election of
1904 is that Parker was hopelessly
overmatched in a personality clash with
President Roosevelt.
That Roosevelt had the more
assertive personality is manifest, but the
implicit statement that the stronger
personality must win is of dubious
merit. Such a rule would not account
for Polk's defeat of Fremont or
McKinley's defeat of Bryan. For this
study, it is most important that it would
not account for Cleveland's 1884 defeat
of James G. Blaine.

Leonine Pose
Blaine can be fitted with virtually
any epithet, and he has been; but there
can be no doubt of the assertiveness of
his personality. In photographs he is
always striking a leonine pose, erect and
somber, with not a whisker askew in his
magnificent full-length beard.
His oratorical style was in keeping
with his personality. Blaine had a voice
of thunder, a reasonable command of
the language and a stage presence that
would command the envy of any
thespian. There is abundant testimony
of his "magnetic" quality; the current
adjective would be "charismatic." In his
best performances, Blaine had the
ability to exact cheers from a hostile
audience.
In the election of 1884, it was clear
from the outset that Blaine and
Cleveland would be battling on the level
of personality contest. There was a
widely diffused impression of Cleveland
which was antithetical to the
marble-and-bronze impression of Blaine.
Cleveland was distinctly unremarkable
.. .... . •

in his presence; he did weigh over 250
pounds, which is somewhat remarkable,
but he was not as attractive as Blaine.
His writing style is prolix and uneven;
he did show some good turns of phrase,
but these are on the simplest level of his
language. Occasionally one discovers
that Cleveland wrote poetry. His poetry,
usually light verse, is uniformly
miserable.
Transports of Work
Obviously the authors of the
Cleveland campaign literature could not
have made him exciting. Instead, it is
stressed that he was a methodical and
deligent worker, and that he would
never fall behind in expediting the
White House paperwork. It appears that,
in his early days as a struggling lawyer in
Buffalo; Cleveland acquired the valuable
habit of struggling until midnight and
sleeping at his desk.
In higher office, his transports of
work were even more impressive.
Lacking the mercurial qualities of
Blaine, he became, both literally and
figuratively, one of the solider citizens
of his community. It was at the bidding
of other solid citizens that he had been
"up and doing" through four years as
Sheriff of Erie County,one as Mayor of
Buffalo and two as Governor of New
York.
There is no need to discuss the
details of the 1884 campaign, but it
must be stressed that the 1904 image of
Parker borrowed heavily from the 1884
image of Cleveland. Roosevelt was not
as questionable in his ethics as Blaine
had been, although, as we shall see,
Parker eventually attempted to fashion
an issue of Roosevelt's ethics. But the
Parker literature pictures Roosevelt as
impetuous and erratic, even as the
Cleveland literature of 1884 had
pictured Blaine. Parker's place with
Cleveland is presented even less subtly.

More Transports
Parker, like Cleveland, is celebrated
for his transports of labor. Parker, like
Cleveland, is known for a devotion to
his family, which hindered his
education. Parker, like Cleveland, is
renowned for his sturdy New England
extraction. Parker, like Cleveland, is
celebrated for assimilating enormous
amounts of material before reaching a
decision. Parker, like Cleveland, is
famous for his devotion to public
service and his methodical, conservative
approach to problems. The two even
appear to share a taste for outdoor
recreation.
It is manifest that the Democrats
were not conceding a personality battle
with Roosevelt. The fact is that, in
elections prior to 1904, the methodical
candidate had faced the mercurial on at
least equal grounds. Grant admittedly
had a dashing reputation, but he was
presented as a solid and sober executive
in two contests against notable orators.
In 1876, both parties stressed their
candidates' methodical application to
piles of work. In 1880 the Republicans
stressed the scholarly and methodical
method of James Garfield, while the
Democrats tried to pump some color
into a campaign for "The Superb
Hancock;" the Superb was narrowly
defeated. Cleveland edged Blaine and
then lost in the Electoral College to

Benjamin Harrison, perhaps the most
colorless of all Presidents. Twice since
then, the wildly exciting Bryan had
been convincingly beaten by the sedate
McKinley.
Conservative Transports
The Parker campaign did not
apologize for its hero's conservatism; it
gloried in it. Cleveland contributed a
magazine sketch of Parker in which the
word "conservative" is a refrain, and
one comes to anticipate its use as one
does Poe's use of "Nevermore."
(Incidentally, magazine sketches of
Roosevelt were usually handled by
Senator Henry Cabot Lodge.)
Just four years before, in the
rematch of McKinley and Bryan, the
vote had been for "safe and sane"
leadership. By the alchemy of
assassination, the Democrats were
putting forth Parker in the role held by
recent winning Republicans and by the
last Democrat to be elected President.
The Democratic candHates were not as
well-known as those of 1884, but they
did have grounds for expecting a close
election.
Nevertheless, it should not be
inferred that the twice-defeated Bryan
was without influence in the campaign.
In my next article I shall commence
consideration of this question with an
examination of the party platform.

By ART LEVINE
No, the news articles will tell you very little about
Cesar Chavez. There is no room in reportage to dwell on
the sweet intangibles of a man's personality. But travel
with him for a short while, and you will be deeply
moved that people like Cesar Chavez still exist in our
country.

His tone, however, is not lifeless and it is not weak.
Chavez is an absolutely dedicated organizer, and he will
not give up."Either the union will be destroyed," he has
said, "or the growers will sign a contract. There's no
other alternative."

The word "saint" is applied loosely these days. Any
person who doesn't beat up old ladies in the street or
rob banks can qualify for it. Chavez, though, has that
truly gently aura of love and compassion that makes him
the nearest thing America has to a true saint.

Yet, again, maybe I am an exception. Maybe the
speech was not so moving as I had imagined, maybe it
was dull and unexciting. But I do not think so. Unless
you are deaf, it is impossible not to be touched by the
sadness in his voice and the horrors he spoke of.
Priests and Chavez
After the speech, to arrange an interview with
Chavez, I had to divid the brief questioning time we
were allowed between myself and some eager young
seminary students. The interview was being taped by
them for something called Ecumedia radio.

He is a small man, but the mixture of Spanish and
Indian blood in him is a handsome one. He has dark,
thick hair, bronzed skin, and soft brown eyes. You can't
forget the eyes, because they are like nothing you will
ever see again. They are bright and deep, and they tell of
a. sadness so profound and a suffering so great that we
simply can't comprehend it. We can't really know about
scratching out a living in the endless nightmare of
migrant farming. We cannot know, we never will know,'
but Chavez is bringing that reality to us, reminding us of
others we never see.
No Fireworks

We crowded into a side room, and as the
photographers took pictures, the seminary students
hovered around Chavez like the disciples around Jesus. It
is not surprising that many church people are devoted to
Chavez. They see the saint in Chavez, and they love him
for it, for he is what they all would like to become.

His whole manner is so totally different from any
other leader I've ever seen. Unlike Martin Luther King or
Eldrige Cleaver or Malcolm X, there is no grandiose
oratory. His speech is not a great cathartic mixture of
pain and joy, it has none of the rich, rolling phrases,
powerful gestures, or electric atmosphere that we have
all come to expect from great crusaders.

Chavez answered our questions patiently. He told us
of the basic problems facing the workers, why he came
to Baltimore, the groups that support him, and how he
was preparing to file suit against the Pentagon. He sat in
a simple chair against the wall, and when he sopke, he
looked into our eyes, earnestly trying to make us
understand the problems he knew so well.

When he came on stage in Shriver Hall, he sat down
quietly next to Jim Archibald and Dr. Wickwire. He was
dressed in a green sweater, dark pants, and grey shoes.
But the crowd stood up before this dark, poised, and
sensitive man, and applauded strongly, a passionate
ovation, because they sensed in their hearts that he had
worked too long to be denied whatever meager tribute
they could give thim. The ovation lacked the usual
Whoopings and whistling, and I was glad for that. I try to
keep up a cynical exterior, and it is not often that I
succumb to the mushy tides of sentiment. Yet that day I
applauded Chavez with the kind of feelings I had not
indulged in for a long time.

Tired Unions
Later, I went to a reception for him at the
Sheraton-Belvedere Hotel. The leaders of the Maryland
labor movement had paid $15 each to see Chavez. I
guess I shouldn't be cynical about their motives, for they
had indeed pushed very hard to make the Baltimore
boycott successful. Yet they were such a tired, corrupt
group of aging labor leaders, with their ill-fitting suits
and pot bellies, that I felt sorry for Chavez because he
had to deal with these people.
Standing around, wolfing down their weenies and
guzzling drinks, these men seemed unaware that Cesar
Chavez was in the room. He sat quietly in the corner,
waiting to speak, as a few burly men occasionally came
over to introduce themselves. They would swagger over,
stick out their hands with a real John Wayne
man-to-man gesture, and Chavez would slowly rise,
smiling shyly.

Dead Souls
He talked softly, with a trace of a Spanish accent. He
was telling us about injustices that were so outrageous
that he did not need to embellish his speech with
rhetorical tricks. He told us of workers being poisoned
and of a Pentagon which doubled its grape purchases in

Chavez was introduced by Nick Fornaro, a husky
man with curly grey hair. Fornaro gave Chavez the same
perfunctory introduction that he has given countless
other speakers before, at receptions no different from
this one. Chavez came to the mike, and the small crowd
clapped politely. The fat wives with their teased hair
stood next to their husbands, and you could tell they
were bored. Their liquor glasses shifted uncomfortably
in their hands as they waited for him to finish. Others, in
the back of the reception room, stood in small groups,
talking among themselves.
No Jokes
Chavez did not change to suit the crowd. He did not
tell them crude jokes to get a quick, drunken laugh, but
sopke briefly in the same soft way about the grape
worker's problems. He spoke once again of the poisoning
of workers, and the people closest to the mike smiled a
glassy-eyed grin of forced sympathy. He told them how
much he appreciated what they had done for him, and I
knew that he meant it.
The next day, in front of the Food Giant
supermarket, Chavez was just another member of ;I
picket line. There was no feverish oratory from a sound
truck, nothing at all that would indicate that the
dark-haired man circling in the line was the Messiah to
five million Mexican-Americans and the leader of a great
national movement.
The picketers were a mixed lot. Union men with
muscle shirts walked side by side with long-haired
students in bell-bottoms. At the same time, a

They're just sympathetic to the cause."
Farm Bureau Sick
According to these sick men of the Farm Bureau, the
migrant worker's life expectancy of 48 years, his hungry
children, and his pitiful income of $800 to $1900 a year
are mere figments of Chavez's imagination.
One lady with mixed brown and greyish hair showed
me what Chavez is up against. As she walked out of the
supermarket in her cheap sunglasses, with her young
blonde daughter beside her she gave an angry look at the

car, she answered my questions about the picketing and
the grape boycott in a tight, mean voice.
"It is just as bad as you kids demonstrating in front
of colleges, and you don't have any reason."
Do you plan to purchase grapes in the future?
"I sure do! If I want the, I can purchase anything I
want, as long as I have a dollar."

In a restrained manner, he said, "It
has been a bitter strike, it has been

Cesar Chavez dealt at length with the
power of the big growers, and the
problems this created for his union.
"The power of the employers is
fantastic, it's even hard to imagine. The
employer owns thousands of acres, and
they literally own everything that lives
there, grows there, and works there.
They own the courts and they own the
police."
Be cause of their power, he
contended, the union faced difficulties
other unions these days don't have to
deal with. "You see, in agriculture we
don't have any of the rules and
regulations that other unions have to go
by. We aren't covered under the
National Labor Relations Act, we're
excluded as workers. It's not enough for
a 100% of the workers to leave the
fields to get recognized. These rules just
don't apply."
Yet Chavez said his union is plagued
by all the anti-union tactics that other

unions must face—including court
injunctions and the hiring of strike
breakers. "The judges are absolutely
free to enjoin every action we take. And
so the injunction is one of the best
methods for the opposition. We have

Commenting on strike-breaking, he
stated, "It doesn't matter how many
workers leave the field, because the
employer can go to Mexico and get as

become the pawns of the employers to
be used against their brothers in the

In response to a question after the
speech, he added, "The moment we
strike, hordes of these people go across
the border to break our strike. We can't

and, of course, there is very little hope

Prior to his speech, a representative
of the Maryland Farm Bureau handed

vehemently attacked the Farm Bureau.
"In America for many years," he,
charged, "the Farm Bureau has done a
good job of opposing any legislation
that's going to benefit the workers.
They • also implanted in the minds of
the American people that all the farmers

The problems his union faced in the
field prompted him, he said, to turn to a

"We know we can't beat the employers
in Delano in the fields, but we know,
because we've already gotten some
employers to sign contracts, that if we
can get thousands and thousands of
people throughout the country involved

audience,"I want to ask you to continue
fighting with us and doing all the things

able, someday, to celebrate a victory

of the bonds of poverty."

The least publicized Varsity sport at Johns Hopkins is
undoubtedly the highly successful Rifle Team, which is open to any
experienced undergraduate marksman on the Homewood campus.

target sheet from a distance of 50 feet with a .22 caliber rifle. There

inches in diameter, and are graded inward from one point on the
outer circle to ten points at the bullseye.
An individual shooter gets ten shots at each target sheet (one for
each individual target) from three positions, (prone, kneeling, and
standing), for a total of three target sheets and thirty shots in all.

"It's too bad the general public doesn't
understand that we are working in their best
interests," lamented Dr. Riley Housewright,

center for chemical and biological warfare
(CBW)research.
Housewright was ordered last ,week by
high-echelon Pentagon officials to back out on a
month-old commitment to discuss the
controversial CBW issue in an appearance at
Hopkins. He complied.

request.

R&D on CBW
Fort Detrick, located in Frederick, Maryland, is the
US center for the research and development of biological
warfare agents. Utilizing the recent advances in genetics,
researchers at the base have been developing techniques
that will enable them to develop a variety of diseases
such as bubonic plague, pneumonic plague, and anthra,

Nearly 3000 civilians and military men work at
Detrick, hoping to discover potential new disease agents
and then learning to defend against them. The work has
been termed "biological ,engineering" by the. germ
warriors of Detrick.

purposes. Its professional staff includes 120 men with
PH.D. degrees in such fields as microbiology and

doctors and 34 veterinarians on its staff. The vets are in

guinea pigs to monkeys which are killed each year in
biological experimentation and similar research.

accidents and excessive secrecy surrounding the entire
program.

By JOHN HOLLIS
"Here I sit so patiently,
Waiting to find out what price
You have to pay to get out of
Going through all these things twice."
So sang Bob Dylan when he had the Memphis blues
again. Now Haskell Wexler, creator of the movie Medium
Cool, has the Chicago blues again. He sits waiting, like
Dylan, daring anyone to escape the harsh truth of the
past and the unavoidable certainty of today.
For Chicago 1968 does happen again, on the screen.
The jeeps, the uniforms, the barricades, the tear gas, the
blood on Michigan Avenue. People in blue jeans, people
in Mayor Daley's back pocket. And you can't pay to get
out of it, cuz it's happening again, right now. Same
place, same channel. Same reasons.
Nothing has changed since August of last year. So
Americans can face the situation the same way they did
August. You can do something: go to Chicago and either
chant your radical lungs out at the cops or throw rocks
and swastikas at the demonstrators.
Eight Million Stories
Or you can lounge comfortably in front of your TV
set, observe the universe through Walter Cronkite's
serious but friendly eyes, mutter something (in a
semi-whisper) about "damn Commie punks", "dirty
Fascist pigs," or "why ain't they in school" (choose
one), and then surrender your untroubled consciousness
to Jed Clampett or Gomer Pyle. Almost everyone will do
that. Less would if more saw Medium Cool.
This movie was written, directed, and photographed
by Haskell Wexler, a craftsman talented in producing
mature modern cinema. There is a story, a realistic story
that would have been on Naked City ("There are eight
million. . .")almost a decade ago. A story about a place
called Chicago, a hard-working .news photographer, his

This story is depicted in the manner of the "dynamic
hard-hitting gutsy" school of cinema. When Wexler
sticks to that, he does fine. But some overworked
gimmicks mar this film. There are the "arty" flashbacks
which are superfluous and tedious. Then there is the
"credibility gap" shot, wherein the camera cuts from
someone's dialogue to an action or setting which
ridicules what that person has just said.
Ravenous Cheering
In this movie the background becomes the
foreground. The story is overshadowed by a larger One,
America at the end of the 1960's. A tale of violence and
anger, of hatred and turmoil. Wexler rewrites the lyrics
to "America the Beautiful" and gives us back what we
gave to history in 1968: a man dead on the floor of a
Los Angeles hotel kitchen, a man dead in a Memphis
motel, a nation dead in the streets and parks of Chicago.
Interspersed among the peaks of history are the
plateaus of non-history that make history: the T-shirt
and curlers crowd cheering ravenously at a roller derby
spectacle, the wives of grocers and insurance salesmen
learning the use of firearms, the black militants
defending looting, the Saturday morning boxing session
at the CYO gym.
A violent America, the America Wexler sees. He
points out important questions about this violence: is
the United States really sick? Does the news media
distort the true picture, encouraging and emphasizing
brutality? But no answer to these unanswerable(though
very fashionable) questions. Unlike a Godard polemic,
we are spared the tedium of some oppressed proletarian
haranguing the bourgeoisie about what the Third World
will do to etc. etc.

Of Course The Tube
We do have to think, though. Unlike the 11:00
o'clock news, there is no Johnny Carson Show after this
movie. The audience. has to walk out of the theatre, get
into its cars and drive home. Then turn on the tube, of
course. But still, a few minutes of thought. There it was,
in full natural color, on a screen enormously larger than
a TV set. No lectures, no speeches. Just the pictures.
Hopefully, it is enough.
But, of course, it is not enough. Medium Cool is a
very, very pessimistic movie. In the most obvious(but
most meaningful) interpretation the two central
characters represent average Americans, non-political
uninvolved Americans. The cameramen, who loves to
shoot film, is just doing his job ("I gotta job ta do,just
like evribody else.") Except for concern for his personal
safety, he never participates in what he photographs.
The woman, from the God-fearin' law-abidin'
countryside, finds herself lost and dazed in the political
violence of Chicago in August 1968. Both remain aloof.
both die.
Everyone Goes On
Medium Cool opens at the scene of an unexplained
car accident. While the car burns, an anonymous man,
walking across a nearby overpass, stares at the twisted
corpse and wrecked automobile. He walks on. Medium
Cool closes at the scene of an unexplained car accident.
A burning station wagon rests in a roadside ditch. A
family cruises by in an ancient Rambler, slowing down
to get a better stare and so the kid can snap the scene
with his Instamatic. They drive on. The soundtrack
broadcasts the screaming of demonstrating radicals, who
say, in a chant both correct and prophetic, "the whole
world is watching."
And so everyone goes on, uninvolved. But no matter
what price you pay, you cannot get out of going through
all this twice. At least twice.

By ED MENDELSOHN
At this point in the study of Alton B.
Parker it is necessary to retreat twenty
years, so that not coincidentally—there
will be a closer examination of the
principal advocate of Parker's election,
former President Cleveland. The
standard comment on the election of
1904 is that Parker was hopelessly
overmatched in a personality clash with
President Roosevelt.
That Roosevelt had the more
assertive personality is manifest, but the
implicit statement that the stronger
personality must win is of dubious
merit. Such a rule would not account
for Polk's defeat of Fremont or
McKinley's defeat of Bryan. For this
study, it is most important that it would
not account for Cleveland's 1884 defeat
of James G. Blaine.

Leonine Pose
Blaine can be fitted with virtually
any epithet, and he has been; but there
can be no doubt of the assertiveness of
his personality. In photographs he is
always striking a leonine pose, erect and
somber, with not a whisker askew in his
magnificent full-length beard.
His oratorical style was in keeping
with his personality. Blaine had a voice
of thunder, a reasonable command of
the language and a stage presence that
would command the envy of any
thespian. There is abundant testimony
of his "magnetic" quality; the current
adjective would be "charismatic." In his
best performances, Blaine had the
ability to exact cheers from a hostile
audience.
In the election of 1884, it was clear
from the outset that Blaine and
Cleveland would be battling on the level
of personality contest. There was a
widely diffused impression of Cleveland
which was antithetical to the
marble-and-bronze impression of Blaine.
Cleveland was distinctly unremarkable
.. .... . •

in his presence; he did weigh over 250
pounds, which is somewhat remarkable,
but he was not as attractive as Blaine.
His writing style is prolix and uneven;
he did show some good turns of phrase,
but these are on the simplest level of his
language. Occasionally one discovers
that Cleveland wrote poetry. His poetry,
usually light verse, is uniformly
miserable.
Transports of Work
Obviously the authors of the
Cleveland campaign literature could not
have made him exciting. Instead, it is
stressed that he was a methodical and
deligent worker, and that he would
never fall behind in expediting the
White House paperwork. It appears that,
in his early days as a struggling lawyer in
Buffalo; Cleveland acquired the valuable
habit of struggling until midnight and
sleeping at his desk.
In higher office, his transports of
work were even more impressive.
Lacking the mercurial qualities of
Blaine, he became, both literally and
figuratively, one of the solider citizens
of his community. It was at the bidding
of other solid citizens that he had been
"up and doing" through four years as
Sheriff of Erie County,one as Mayor of
Buffalo and two as Governor of New
York.
There is no need to discuss the
details of the 1884 campaign, but it
must be stressed that the 1904 image of
Parker borrowed heavily from the 1884
image of Cleveland. Roosevelt was not
as questionable in his ethics as Blaine
had been, although, as we shall see,
Parker eventually attempted to fashion
an issue of Roosevelt's ethics. But the
Parker literature pictures Roosevelt as
impetuous and erratic, even as the
Cleveland literature of 1884 had
pictured Blaine. Parker's place with
Cleveland is presented even less subtly.

More Transports
Parker, like Cleveland, is celebrated
for his transports of labor. Parker, like
Cleveland, is known for a devotion to
his family, which hindered his
education. Parker, like Cleveland, is
renowned for his sturdy New England
extraction. Parker, like Cleveland, is
celebrated for assimilating enormous
amounts of material before reaching a
decision. Parker, like Cleveland, is
famous for his devotion to public
service and his methodical, conservative
approach to problems. The two even
appear to share a taste for outdoor
recreation.
It is manifest that the Democrats
were not conceding a personality battle
with Roosevelt. The fact is that, in
elections prior to 1904, the methodical
candidate had faced the mercurial on at
least equal grounds. Grant admittedly
had a dashing reputation, but he was
presented as a solid and sober executive
in two contests against notable orators.
In 1876, both parties stressed their
candidates' methodical application to
piles of work. In 1880 the Republicans
stressed the scholarly and methodical
method of James Garfield, while the
Democrats tried to pump some color
into a campaign for "The Superb
Hancock;" the Superb was narrowly
defeated. Cleveland edged Blaine and
then lost in the Electoral College to

Benjamin Harrison, perhaps the most
colorless of all Presidents. Twice since
then, the wildly exciting Bryan had
been convincingly beaten by the sedate
McKinley.
Conservative Transports
The Parker campaign did not
apologize for its hero's conservatism; it
gloried in it. Cleveland contributed a
magazine sketch of Parker in which the
word "conservative" is a refrain, and
one comes to anticipate its use as one
does Poe's use of "Nevermore."
(Incidentally, magazine sketches of
Roosevelt were usually handled by
Senator Henry Cabot Lodge.)
Just four years before, in the
rematch of McKinley and Bryan, the
vote had been for "safe and sane"
leadership. By the alchemy of
assassination, the Democrats were
putting forth Parker in the role held by
recent winning Republicans and by the
last Democrat to be elected President.
The Democratic candHates were not as
well-known as those of 1884, but they
did have grounds for expecting a close
election.
Nevertheless, it should not be
inferred that the twice-defeated Bryan
was without influence in the campaign.
In my next article I shall commence
consideration of this question with an
examination of the party platform.

By ART LEVINE
No, the news articles will tell you very little about
Cesar Chavez. There is no room in reportage to dwell on
the sweet intangibles of a man's personality. But travel
with him for a short while, and you will be deeply
moved that people like Cesar Chavez still exist in our
country.

His tone, however, is not lifeless and it is not weak.
Chavez is an absolutely dedicated organizer, and he will
not give up."Either the union will be destroyed," he has
said, "or the growers will sign a contract. There's no
other alternative."

The word "saint" is applied loosely these days. Any
person who doesn't beat up old ladies in the street or
rob banks can qualify for it. Chavez, though, has that
truly gently aura of love and compassion that makes him
the nearest thing America has to a true saint.

Yet, again, maybe I am an exception. Maybe the
speech was not so moving as I had imagined, maybe it
was dull and unexciting. But I do not think so. Unless
you are deaf, it is impossible not to be touched by the
sadness in his voice and the horrors he spoke of.
Priests and Chavez
After the speech, to arrange an interview with
Chavez, I had to divid the brief questioning time we
were allowed between myself and some eager young
seminary students. The interview was being taped by
them for something called Ecumedia radio.

He is a small man, but the mixture of Spanish and
Indian blood in him is a handsome one. He has dark,
thick hair, bronzed skin, and soft brown eyes. You can't
forget the eyes, because they are like nothing you will
ever see again. They are bright and deep, and they tell of
a. sadness so profound and a suffering so great that we
simply can't comprehend it. We can't really know about
scratching out a living in the endless nightmare of
migrant farming. We cannot know, we never will know,'
but Chavez is bringing that reality to us, reminding us of
others we never see.
No Fireworks

We crowded into a side room, and as the
photographers took pictures, the seminary students
hovered around Chavez like the disciples around Jesus. It
is not surprising that many church people are devoted to
Chavez. They see the saint in Chavez, and they love him
for it, for he is what they all would like to become.

His whole manner is so totally different from any
other leader I've ever seen. Unlike Martin Luther King or
Eldrige Cleaver or Malcolm X, there is no grandiose
oratory. His speech is not a great cathartic mixture of
pain and joy, it has none of the rich, rolling phrases,
powerful gestures, or electric atmosphere that we have
all come to expect from great crusaders.

Chavez answered our questions patiently. He told us
of the basic problems facing the workers, why he came
to Baltimore, the groups that support him, and how he
was preparing to file suit against the Pentagon. He sat in
a simple chair against the wall, and when he sopke, he
looked into our eyes, earnestly trying to make us
understand the problems he knew so well.

When he came on stage in Shriver Hall, he sat down
quietly next to Jim Archibald and Dr. Wickwire. He was
dressed in a green sweater, dark pants, and grey shoes.
But the crowd stood up before this dark, poised, and
sensitive man, and applauded strongly, a passionate
ovation, because they sensed in their hearts that he had
worked too long to be denied whatever meager tribute
they could give thim. The ovation lacked the usual
Whoopings and whistling, and I was glad for that. I try to
keep up a cynical exterior, and it is not often that I
succumb to the mushy tides of sentiment. Yet that day I
applauded Chavez with the kind of feelings I had not
indulged in for a long time.

Tired Unions
Later, I went to a reception for him at the
Sheraton-Belvedere Hotel. The leaders of the Maryland
labor movement had paid $15 each to see Chavez. I
guess I shouldn't be cynical about their motives, for they
had indeed pushed very hard to make the Baltimore
boycott successful. Yet they were such a tired, corrupt
group of aging labor leaders, with their ill-fitting suits
and pot bellies, that I felt sorry for Chavez because he
had to deal with these people.
Standing around, wolfing down their weenies and
guzzling drinks, these men seemed unaware that Cesar
Chavez was in the room. He sat quietly in the corner,
waiting to speak, as a few burly men occasionally came
over to introduce themselves. They would swagger over,
stick out their hands with a real John Wayne
man-to-man gesture, and Chavez would slowly rise,
smiling shyly.

Dead Souls
He talked softly, with a trace of a Spanish accent. He
was telling us about injustices that were so outrageous
that he did not need to embellish his speech with
rhetorical tricks. He told us of workers being poisoned
and of a Pentagon which doubled its grape purchases in

Chavez was introduced by Nick Fornaro, a husky
man with curly grey hair. Fornaro gave Chavez the same
perfunctory introduction that he has given countless
other speakers before, at receptions no different from
this one. Chavez came to the mike, and the small crowd
clapped politely. The fat wives with their teased hair
stood next to their husbands, and you could tell they
were bored. Their liquor glasses shifted uncomfortably
in their hands as they waited for him to finish. Others, in
the back of the reception room, stood in small groups,
talking among themselves.
No Jokes
Chavez did not change to suit the crowd. He did not
tell them crude jokes to get a quick, drunken laugh, but
sopke briefly in the same soft way about the grape
worker's problems. He spoke once again of the poisoning
of workers, and the people closest to the mike smiled a
glassy-eyed grin of forced sympathy. He told them how

(CPS)--The San Francisco Federal court has handed
down a draft decision that could significantly disturb
draft procedures while freeing a number of present
1-Aers from induction.
Judge Robert Peckham ruled this week that the
universally enforced regulation which prevents draft
registrants from being accompanied by legal counsel
when summoned before a local draft board is invalid and
"constitutionally suspect." Judge Peckham was the
magistrate who ruled earlier this year that members of
draft boards must be residents of the area from which
they send men.
Those men who have appeared before draft boards,
usually on summonses for being delinquent in
registration, and who have stood mute or requested the
assistance of an attorney or counsel have normally been
held in contempt and classified 1-A. Their classifications
are now invalid, and most draft boards will most likely
ignore them rather than submit them to the legal
procedures necessary to change the person's
classification or validate the 1-A status.
Judge Peckham clearly ruled that only Congress can
refuse the right of counsel for any person being
interrogated by federal institutions and that no legal
delegation of this power has ever been granted to the
President (and through him local draft boards). The
challenge affects all draft boards under government
jurisdiction unless it is overruled in a higher court.
